highlights.para: Welcome to the OpenSolaris 2008.11 Package Manager Online Help!
Use this help contents to learn how to use the Package Manager. Navigate through this help by clicking on the topics displayed in the side bar.
The OpenSolaris 2008.11 Package Manager application is a graphical user interface for the Image Packaging System (IPS) software.
The Package Manager enables you to perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: Search, install and remove packages.
Add and modify repositories.
Create, remove and manage boot environments.

note.para: See the for a table of terms and definitions used in the Package Manager Online Help document.

sect1.title: Package Manager Screencast
sect1.para: Learn how to use the OpenSolaris 2008.11 Package Manager through a screencast. Click here to go the Package Manager screencast.

sect1.title: Starting Package Manager
sect1.para: You can start the Package Manager in the following ways:

listitem.para: Click SystemAdministrationPackage Manager.
Run the following command :

sect1.title: Package Manager Window
sect1.para: When you start the Package Manager, the following window is displayed:
The main window of the Package Manager consists of the following elements :

listitem.para: You can browse the available packages by category in the left hand side drop-down menu. The drop-down menu shows the list of categories available such as Applications-Desktop, Applications Web based, and Operating System.
The Show drop-down menu enables you to filter the list of packages by the following options:
All Packages– Shows the list of all packages available in the current (todo) repository.
Installed Packages – Shows the list of packages installed on your system.
Updates Available — Shows the list of packages that have newer versions available in the current repository.
Non-installed Packages – Shows the list of packages that are not installed, but are available in the currently selected repository.
Selected Packages – Shows the list of packages that you have selected.
The toolbar contains the icons for a subset of the commands that can be performed by using the menus on the menubar.
The Repositories drop-down menu is also located on the toolbar.
You can access the menus on the menubar to perform all of the commands related to the Package Manager.
The list of packages in the selected category, a brief description, and their status are displayed here.
Click a package to select it. Details of the selected package such as name, version, file dependencies, and license are displayed in this window.
The list of available repositories is shown in the repository drop-down menu. Click a repository name to select it.

note.para: Click the Reload button to reload the Package Manager and view the list of packages from the newly selected repository.

highlights.para: The following sections document the tasks that can be performed with the Package Manager.

sect1.title: Install a Package
sect1.para: Perform the following steps to install a package:

listitem.para: In the main window of the Package Manager, click the Reload button to view the latest list of packages available to you.
Check the box next to the package(s) to select it.
Click Install/Update in the toolbar to start the package installation process.
You can also choose PackageInstall/Update to start the package installation process.
The Package Manager checks for dependencies. Click Show Details to view the details.
Click Cancel to cancel the package installation. No changes are made and you are returned to the main window.
The Install Confirmation dialog box is displayed. Review the package installation information and the package dependencies details.
Click Next to proceed with the package installation.
Click Cancel to cancel the package installation. No changes are made and you are returned to the main window.
The Downloading Packages dialog box is displayed.
Click Cancel to cancel the package installation. No changes are made and you are returned to the main window.

sect1.para: The packages are installed. The updated list of packages are displayed in the main window.

sect1.title: Remove a Package
sect1.para: Perform the following steps to remove a package:

listitem.para: Check the box next to the package(s) that you want to remove.
Click the Remove button in the toolbar to start the process.
You can also choose PackageRemove to remove a package.
The Remove Confirmation dialog box is displayed. Review the packages to be removed and the package dependencies details.
Click Proceed to confirm. After you click the OK button, you cannot undo the package removal.
Click Cancel to cancel the process. No changes are made and you are returned to the main window.

sect1.title: Search for a Package
sect1.para: Type the name of the package that you want to search for in the Search box.
The following search parameters are available:

listitem.para: Name, Description –
Maintainer –
Dependencies –
Commands –

tip.para: Use the button on the right hand side of the Search tab to clear the search results.

sect1.para: Use the submenus under the Edit menu to cut, copy, paste, or clear text in the Search tab.

sect1.title: Update a Package
sect1.para: Look for the green icon next to the installed package name. This icon indicates that updates are available for the package in the currently selected repository. Select the package and click the Install/Update button to install the latest version of the package.

sect1.title: Switch Between Configured Repositories
sect1.para: Use the Repositories drop-down menu on the toolbar to view a list of configured repositories. Click a repository name to switch to a different repository.

sect1.title: Update the Current Image (Update All Packages)
sect1.para: <insert link about BEs here>.
Perform the following steps to update all the packages in your image.

listitem.para: Click the Update All button to start the process of updating all the packages in your image.
You can also choose FileUpdate All to start the process.

note.para: The Update All button is enabled when updates are available to the installed packages.

listitem.para: The Update All Confirmation dialog box is displayed.

During the Update All process, a clone of the active boot environment is created. This clone enables the user to boot into the boot environment state that existed before the Update All process was started.

note.para: A name for the new boot environment is automatically created.

listitem.para: Click Proceed to continue the Update All process.
Click Cancel to cancel the process. No changes are made to the boot environment and you are returned to the main window of the Package Manager.

para.emphasis: Reboot your system for the changes to become effective.

sect2.title: Update All Errors
sect2.para: A new boot environment clone must be created for the Update All process to be completed. An error message dialog box is displayed if a boot environment clone cannot be created. You might see an error message such as :
Not enough disk space: the Update All action cannot be performed. You may choose to return to BE Management to manage your boot environments and free up disk space.
Perform the following steps if you want to rectify the error and continue with the Update All process:

listitem.para: Click the BE Management button in the error dialog box to open the BE Management dialog box.
Follow the steps listed in to delete old or unused boot environments and free up disk space.
Reboot your system.
Click the Update All icon to restart the process of updating all packages.

sect1.title: Manage Boot Environments
sect1.para: Perform the following steps to manage your boot environments (BEs) :

listitem.para: Click FileBoot Environment Management .
The Boot Environment Management dialog box is displayed. In this dialog box, you can perform the following actions:
Select the boot environment that you want to be active on system reboot. This is the default boot environment.

term.emphasis: Remove old or unused boot environments to free up disk space.

listitem.para: Select the boot environment(s) you want to delete.
Click OK to proceed.
Click Reset to reset the changes and show the initial state.
Click Cancel to cancel all changes and return to the main window.
If you clicked OK , the BE Management Confirmation dialog box is displayed. Review the changes to the boot environment(s) and click OK to proceed.

warning.para: After you click OK, you cannot undo any changes you made to the the boot environment(s).

note.para: The changes that you made to the default boot environment setting are effective only after system reboot.

listitem.para: Click Cancel to cancel the changes and return to the BE Management dialog box.
Reboot your system to boot into the new default boot environment.

sect1.title: Edit Repositories
sect1.para: Perform the following steps to add, remove, or configure repositories:

listitem.para: Choose SettingsEdit Repositories.
The Manage Repositories dialog box is displayed. In this dialog box, you can perform the following actions :
Add a Repository – To add a new repository, type the name and the address (URL) of the repository. Click Add.
Remove a Repository – To remove a repository, click a repository name from the list to select it. Click Remove.

note.para: A repository that has been set as preferred repository cannot be removed. To remove a preferred repository, set a nonpreferred repository as preferred, and then remove the repository.

listitem.para: To set a repository as a preferred repository, click the radio button next to the repository that you would like to set as the preferred repository. Click Close if you are not making any other changes to the repository information.
Modify a Repository – Perform the following steps to modify a repository :
Select the repository that you want to modify.
Click the Modify button.
The Modify Repository dialog box is displayed.
Type a valid name for the repository and the URL of the repository.
A repository name is considered valid if it does not exist in the current list of repositories.
Click OK to save the changes and return to the Manage Repositories dialog box.
Click Cancel to cancel your changes. You are returned to the Manage Repositories dialog box.

glossdef.para: A package is a collection of files, directories, links, drivers and dependencies in a defined format.

listitem.para: An authority designs, creates, and publishes a package to a repository.

An authority can also be a location that is configured to point to a repository and may contain additional information about the package such as the publisher of the package. The repository, in turn, serves the packages from the (default) authority, for downloading purposes

glossdef.para: A default repository that is the source for packages. If a user does not explicitly specify a repository, the preferred authority is chosen as the source for packages.
A repository is a location where packages are available for download.

For an OpenSolaris release, a boot environment is an instance of a bootable OpenSolaris environment. The boot environment consists of a root file system and, optionally, other file systems, such as /usr, /var, or /export. These other file systems are mounted below the root file system. The root file system and all other file systems of the boot environment that contain system software are required to be zfs datasets.

The active boot environment is the one that is currently booted. Exactly one active boot environment can be booted. An inactive boot environment is not currently booted, but can be in a state of waiting for activation on the next reboot.
A clone is an exact copy. For installation, this could be an exact copy of an operating system, a file system, or a volume. This copy has 100% compatibility with the original.

A limited installation of package files. Only those files that have been modified are installed. If files have been removed from the package that is to be installed, those same files are removed from the package that is being updated.
